0.0: Mishnah: Partners agree to make a division in a courtyard; they build a wall in the middle.
0.1: In a place where the custom is to build with rough stone, smooth stones, half-bricks, or bricks, they must build according to the custom of the land. ...
0.2: If rough-stones, he gives 3 hand-breadths  (9 cm/hand-breadth) and the other gives 3 hand-breadths.
0.3: If smooth stones, he gives 2.5 hand-breadths and the other gives 2.5 hand-breadths. ...
0.4: If half-bricks, he gives 2 hand-breadths and the other gives 2 hand-breadths.
0.5: If bricks, he gives 1.5 hand-breadths and the other gives 1.5 hand-breadths....
0.6: Therefore, if the wall falls, the place where the wall and the materials were will belong to both of them.
0.7: Similarly in a garden; In a place where the custom is to build a fence, you can force the other to build.
0.8: Oppositely in a wheat field, in a place where there isn't a custom to build a fence, you cannot force the other. Rather, if you want to build your own wall, build the wall on your side with a marking facing outwards.
0.9: Therefore, if the wall falls, the place where the wall and the bricks were will belong to you.
0.10: If both of you want to build a wall, both should mark their sides.
0.11: Therefore, if the wall falls, the land and the bricks will belong to both of them:
0.13: a wall, they show a case (proving it) ,

2.0: Redeeming captives is a great mitzvah.
2.1: Rava said to Rabbah bar Mari:
2.2: From where is this statement of the Sages [derived], that redeeming captives is a great mitzvah?
2.3: He responded: as it is written:
2.4: (Jeremiah 15, 2) "And it shall come to pass, when they say unto thee: Whither shall we go forth? then thou shall tell them: Thus saith the LORD: Such as are for death, to death; and such as are for the sword, to the sword; and such as are for the famine, to the famine; and such as are for captivity, to captivity."
2.6: As we go in to the verse, each part is harsher than the previous ones.
2.7: The sword is worse than death.
2.8: If you want, you can say that it is from a verse, and if you want, you can say that it is from logical reasoning.
2.9: If you want to say that it is from logical reasoning:
2.10: This one is a disgrace, and this one is not.
2.11: If you want to say that it is from a verse:
2.12: (Psalms 116, 15) "Precious in the sight of the LORD Is the death of His saints."
2.14: If you want to say that it is from logical reasoning:
2.15: This one, he suffers, that one, he does not suffer.
2.16: If you want to say that it is from a verse:
2.17: (Lamentations 4, 9) "They that are slain with the sword are better Than they that are slain with hunger"
2.18: Captivity is the worst of all, for it contains all of them.

9.0: Apply the last part to the children of the school, from the time of the decree of Yehoshua ben Gamla and on.
9.1: For Rav Yehuda said in the name of Rav:
9.2: However, remember this man for good, namely Yehoshua ben Gamla, for if not for him, Torah would have been forgotten from Israel.
9.3: For originally, whoever had a father, [the father] would teach him Torah; whoever had no father would not learn Torah.
9.7: They decreed that teachers of children should be set up in Jerusalem.
9.9: (Isaiah 2:3) "For out of Zion shall go forth the law."
9.10: But still, whoever had a father, [the father] would bring him up [to Jerusalem] and teach him; whoever didn't have a father would not go up and learn.
9.11: They decreed that [teachers] should be set up in each and every district.
9.12: And they would bring them in at around age 16 or 17, and anyone whose teacher was angry at him, [the teacher] would kick him out.
9.13: Until Yehoshua ben Gamla came and decreed that teachers of children should be set up in each and every province and in each and every city, and [that] they are brought in at around age 6 or 7.

text.10: Rav Huna the son of Rav Yehoshua said: It is quite clear to me that the residents of one town can prevent the resident of another town [from setting up in competition in this town], but not, however, if he pays taxes to that town; and that the resident of an alley cannot prevent another resident of the same alley [from setting up in competition in his alley].

11.1: ... A non-irrigated field's presumptive right is three years, and is not day to day
11.3: ... 3 months in the beginning (of year one) 3 [months] in the end (year 3) and 12 months in the middle, 18 months in total
11.5: ...a month in the beginning (of year one) a month in the end (of year 3) and 12 months in the middle, 14 months in total
11.7: ...My previous statement applies to a cornfield, but regarding a field of trees, if one harvests the produce, gathers the olives, and harvests the figs [all in one year], that is [equivalent to] three years.

Here too, since one ate three years, [the property] goes out from the domain of the seller and is established in the domain of the buyer

17.0: It was taught: The daughters of Zelophehad were exceedingly wise, knew well how to expound Scripture, and were perfectly virtuous. They were exceedingly wise since they chose to speak at the right time; for just then ... Moses our teacher was engaged in interpreting the section on levirate marriage. So they said, "If in levirate marriage our status is like that of sons [ie, it is only relevant if a father dies without sons or daughters], , then give us, like a son a possession in the land. If not, then our Mother should be subjected to a levirate marriage. At once, "Moses brought their cause before the Lord." The daughters also knew well how to expound Scripture [learn from the Torah] for they said, "If our father had a son, we would not have spoken, or even if that son had a daughter, we would not have spoken." They were also perfectly virtuous, since they married only men who were worthy of them."
